subtitle: It hurts when I pass water
title: It hurts when I pass water
content:
Created by BabyCenter

Your baby is growing inside your body just above your bladder (where your water collects before you pass it). The weight of the baby tends to squash the bladder, which makes you need to pass water (called urine) more often. This is common in pregnancy. Do not cut down the amount of clean, safe water you drink. You need it to stay healthy.

If you find that it is painful when you pass water, you might have an infection. This can give you a high temperature, or make you suddenly feel hot and cold. Other signs of infection are blood in your urine, feeling sick, and shaking. Sex might be painful, too.

Getting treated is very important, so see a nurse or midwife. The germs in your urine can give you a kidney infection, which can be serious for your and your baby’s health.

You can also help to prevent urine infections.

•	After going to the toilet, always wipe from 'front' to 'back', or pour water from front to back, or wash with soap.

•	Drink lots of clean, safe water. This will help to wash out infections.

•	If you need to pass water, go! Do not hold it in.

Always pass water after sex, if you can, to get rid of any germs.
